html:
Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈpiː.pi.oː/
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈpi.pi.o/, [ˈpiː.pi.ɔ]

Etymology 1[edit]

Derived from pīpiō (“I chirp”), of imitative origin.

Noun[edit]

pīpiō f (genitive pīpiōnis); third declension

  1. chirping bird
  2. squab
Declension[edit]

Third-declension noun.

Case Singular Plural
Nominative pīpiō pīpiōnēs
Genitive pīpiōnis pīpiōnum
Dative pīpiōnī pīpiōnibus
Accusative pīpiōnem pīpiōnēs
Ablative pīpiōne pīpiōnibus
Vocative pīpiō pīpiōnēs
Descendants[edit]
  • Old French: pyjon
    • Middle French: pigeon
      • English: pigeon
      • French: pigeon, pigeonneau
      • Norman: pigeon
  • Italian: piccione
    • Greek: πιτσούνι (pitsoúni)
    • Spanish: pichón
  • Sardinian: piccioni
  • Sicilian: picciuni
    • Maltese: beċċun
  • Spanish: pipiolo

Etymology 2[edit]

Of imitative origin.

Verb[edit]

pīpiō (present infinitive pīpīre); fourth conjugation, no passive, no perfect or supine stem

  1. I pipe or chirp
Conjugation[edit]

Etymology 3[edit]

From the previous verb.

Verb[edit]

pīpiō (present infinitive pīpiāre, perfect active pīpiāvī, supine pīpiātum); first conjugation

  1. I whimper
  2. (transitive) I pour out (whimpers)
